ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

MINDEF CAREER DEVELOPMENT UNIT


    1. Mr Teo Chong Tee asked the First Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Defence whether his Ministry will set up a career development unit to enable representatives of private business enterprises to conduct induction talks for full-time national servicemen so as to prepare them for jobs prior to their Run-Out-Date and whether there is an employment service available to assist them in getting a job in the private or public sector after their ROD.

     The Second Minister for Defence (Services) (BG Lee Hsien Loong) (for the First Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Defence): Mr Speaker, Sir, I am answering on behalf of my Minister.

    Prior to 1975, MINDEF ran a job placement service for national servicemen. This service was discontinued because the healthy employment market made it redundant. In a growing economy, National Servicemen, like others in the job

Column: 8

market, have been able to find jobs on their own without any difficulty. Their National Service training, discipline and self-confidence stand them in good stead for any job.

    National Service reservists work in well over 55,000 companies. Every employer in Singapore is potentially an employer of national servicemen. To allow employers to conduct induction talks for national servicemen before ROD would be impracticable and highly disruptive to the training programmes.

Column: 8

NATIONAL SERVICE ENLISTMENT
(Figures)


    2. Mr Teo Chong Tee asked the First Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Defence how many full-time national servicemen had signed on in each of the defence forces for the years 1984 to 1986 and whether he considers the intake in each of the categories satisfactory.

Column: 9



     BG Lee Hsien Loong (for the First Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Defence): Mr Speaker, Sir, as a matter of policy, MINDEF does not release manpower or recruitment figures for the armed services. However, MINDEF sets recruitment standards which ensure that the persons recruited are fit and able to fulfil their operational roles in the services, and sets terms and conditions of service sufficiently attractive so that MINDEF is able to recruit the manpower it needs from the national talent pool. By these criteria, the record of the past few years in all three services has been satisfactory.

HDB RELOCATION SCHEME
(Particulars)


    3. Mr Chng Hee Kok asked the Minister for National Development if the Housing and Development Board will give the number of flats affected by the relocation scheme and the target date by which the exercise will be completed.

    4. Dr S. Vasoo asked the Minister for National Development (a) how many families have taken up flats under the Housing and Development Board's relocation scheme as at the latest date; (b) what types of flats have families affected by relocation applied for; and (c) what other actions, besides payment of compensation, are being undertaken by the HDB to minimise the difficulties facing households affected by relocation.

     The Minister for National Development (Mr S. Dhanabalan): Mr Speaker, Sir, since Questions 3 and 4 deal with the same subject, may I have your permission to deal with them together?

     Mr Speaker: Yes.

     Mr Dhanabalan: Sir, the HDB Relocation Programme is planned to be carried out in phases. About 20,000 tenants in 357 blocks are affected under the first phase of the exercise. The target date for the completion of this phase is the last quarter of 1988. The other phases are under review to take into account the experience gained in the current exercise.

    As at 30th September 1987, 20,363 tenants had registered for alternative accommodation under the Relocation Programme. Of these, 10,624 (52%) opted for

Column: 10

alternative rental flats and 9,739 (48%) opted to buy flats. So far, 12,216 have already accepted alternative accommodation comprising 6,226 who accepted rental flats and 5,990 who accepted home ownership flats.

    In addition to the payment of removal allowance for those who cannot afford to buy flats, the HDB will try to rehouse them in rental flats either within the neighbourhood or in adjoining estates wherever this is possible. This should help to minimize the difficulties faced by such tenants.

     Mr Chiam See Tong (Potong Pasir): Mr Speaker, Sir, how much is the removal allowance which the HDB is paying now?

     Mr Dhanabalan: Sir, speaking from memory, I think it is $500 and $1,000.

     Mr Chng Hee Kok (Radin Mas): Sir, will the Minister explain what is the action contemplated by the HDB on those tenants who still remain towards the end of the target date?

     Mr Dhanabalan: Sir, the intention is to clear all these blocks and they have been given notice. They will be persuaded to move out to other flats, either rental flats or persuaded to buy flats. The same procedure will be adopted as and when we clear any area. If necessary, they will be physically removed.

     Dr S. Vasoo (Bo Wen): Sir, could the Minister relocate old people and old couples within the same neighbourhood and not to other neighbourhoods which would cause problems to them?

     Mr Dhanabalan: Mr Speaker, Sir, this is a group that we pay particular attention to, the old people, two single people sharing a flat and other similar cases. We give them special attention and we try and rehouse them as far as possible in the same neighbourhood or very near their present abode.

CHOLERA AT PELANGI HOME
(Measures to prevent recurrence)


    5. Mr Abdullah Tarmugi asked the Minister for the Environment what was the cause of the cholera outbreak at Pelangi

Column: 11

Home recently and what measures are being taken to prevent further occurrences in this and other welfare institutions.

    6. Mr Ng Kah Ting asked the Minister for the Environment (a) what caused the cholera outbreak at Pelangi Home resulting in the death of one inmate and 17 others being warded; (b) whether this was the first outbreak in the Home; and (c) what steps have been taken to ensure that there will be no further outbreaks in Homes.

     The Minister for the Environment (Dr Ahmad Mattar): Mr Speaker, Sir, may I seek your permission to reply to Question 6 as well because the two questions are similar?

     Mr Speaker: Yes.

     Dr Ahmad Mattar: The cause of the recent outbreak of cholera in Pelangi Home has not yet been established. Investigations are still in progress. A total of 19 residents came down with cholera and one of them died.

    Food was not prepared in the Home. All the meals were supplied by a licensed caterer. No cholera germs were detected in any of the food samples collected and all the food handlers screened were found to be free from cholera-carrier state. The water supply to the Home was safe and there was no evidence of it being contaminated with cholera germs. The Home was well maintained and the sanitation in the Home including the toilets were generally satisfactory.

    The Pelangi Home is an institution for burnt-out mental patients discharged from Woodbridge Hospital. Many of the inmates are not capable of ensuring good personal hygiene. It is likely that the poor personal hygiene of the inmates led to the rapid spread of infection within the Home after one of them came down with cholera.

    The Pelangi Home has been in existence for the past three years and no cholera case or outbreak has previously been reported.

    The key to the prevention and control of cholera outbreak in the Home and other

Column: 12

welfare institutions is maintenance of a high standard of environmental sanitation. Staff in these institutions should pay special attention to the personal and food hygiene of the inmates. They have also to actively look out for diarrhoeal cases among the inmates and isolate them immediately at the Communicable Disease Centre of Tan Tock Seng Hospital.

     Mr Ng Kah Ting (Punggol): Mr Speaker, Sir, after giving such advice to the Homes concerned, may I ask of the Minister for the Environment what follow-up action will be taken to ensure compliance?

     Dr Ahmad Mattar: Mr Speaker Sir, we do take follow-up action. Environmental health officers of my Ministry are now conducting monthly visits on the Home and they will continue to do so for at least another six months to ensure that the required standard of cleanliness and hygiene is maintained.

PORT OF SINGAPORE


    7. Dr Arthur Beng Kian Lam asked the Minister for Communications and Information what steps are being taken to ensure that there will be no congestion at our port, now that the economy is picking up, and that our port will continue to maintain its premier position as the busiest port in the world, in the light of competition from other ports.

     The Minister for Communications and Information (Dr Yeo Ning Hong): Mr Speaker, Sir, in the first nine months of this year, containerised cargo at our Port increased by 21% to reach 28 million tonnes. General cargo throughput also increased by 16%, compared with the same period last year, to 38 million tonnes.

    Thanks to long-term planning, our Port has been able to accommodate these substantial increases without any adverse effect. The port continues to maintain a high level of productivity. On the average, the port turns a container ship around in about seven hours, handling something like 600 containers. This turnaround time is one of the fastest in the world. It means much lower costs for shipowners as well as shippers.

Column: 13



    As for the foreseeable future, we expect containerised cargo to continue to increase. To meet this expected growth, the Port of Singapore Authority (PSA) is increasing the capacity of its existing container facilities by adding more quay cranes and other handling equipment. These cranes will be computerized to handle fourth-generation container vessels even more efficiently. The contract for 10 such cranes, amounting to $55 million, was recently awarded.

    PSA is also converting two conventional berths into a container berth at a cost of about $30 million. The new container berth will be ready in the second half of next year. This additional berth will be equipped with the latest container handling facilities and should be sufficient to meet the expected growth up to 1992.

    Beyond 1992, PSA plans to develop a new container terminal on Pulau Brani. Pulau Brani will have a modern terminal with maximum use of automation, mechanization and computerization in all its operations. Pulau Brani will also be linked to the mainland by a causeway. This will help reduce land transport time for importers and exporters as well as for sea-air freighters.

    Singapore intends to maintain its position as the world's busiest port. For the first nine months of this year, shipping tonnage calling at Singapore increased by another 4%, bringing the total tonnage to 250 million gross registered tonnes. We will ensure that our port services are efficient and that our port charges competitive. We will strive for higher standards of productivity to give lower costs and to streamline port tariffs to maintain competitiveness. New computer hardware will be acquired and software developed to improve planning as well as to facilitate information and communication between the port, port users as well as the relevant Government departments. More aggressive marketing programmes will also be initiated to attract more ships and cargo to Singapore. No effort will be spared to maintain our position as the premier port internationally.

NATIONAL LION SYMBOL
(Response to use)


    8. Dr Arthur Beng Kian Lam asked the Minister for Communications and Information what the response has been from both the public and private sectors to the use of our National Symbol, since it was launched in 1986.

     Dr Yeo Ning Hong: Sir, since the National Lion Symbol was launched in July last year as an integral part of the National Day Celebrations, it has been well received by the public. This is evident by its wide usage by private corporations, community organizations as well as the public sector. You can see the Lion Symbol almost everywhere, on buses, taxis, banners, letterheads, and so forth.

    To illustrate how popular the Symbol has been: Members will recall that earlier this year my Ministry produced some collar pins with the Lion Symbol and distributed them at the last National Day Parade to participants and spectators. The pins proved to be so popular that private and public sector organizations have, on their own, ordered an additional 200,000 pins for the use of their members and staff.

    Nationwide, the response to the National Symbol has been very positive. So far, more than 150 organizations have used or are still using the Symbol in various ways in printed materials, advertisements, products and activities. I would like to thank all the organizations for taking pride in identifying themselves with our National Symbol and in their own way publicly declaring their loyalty to Singapore. I hope more organizations will follow their lead.

    Sir, with your permission, I would ask the Clerk of Parliament to circulate a list of items which have incorporated our National Lion Symbol.

    [Copies of document distributed to hon. Members.]

    These examples will make it easier for other organizations to use their ingenuity to develop new ways of using the National Symbol.

CRIME IN HDB NEW TOWNS
(Particulars)


    9. Mr S. Chandra Das asked the Minister for Home Affairs what are the types and number of crimes frequently committed in Housing and Development Board new towns, especially in Ang Mo Kio; and what further measures will be introduced to reduce the crime levels.

     The Minister for Home Affairs (Prof. S. Jayakumar): Mr Speaker, Sir, the crimes most commonly committed in public housing estates are robbery, housebreaking, motor vehicle theft and vandalism. There were 5,672 such offences in 1986. The number up to September this year was 4,786. In Ang Mo Kio a total of 435 cases was reported for the period January to September this year. For the same period last year the total was 333 cases. The overall increase was attributed mainly to motor vehicle theft and vandalism.

    The Police are monitoring the crime levels. In the problem areas extensive patrols and ambushes are carried out. Where appropriate, special operations have also been mounted for some of these offences. The Police will step up their policing efforts through more Police presence and anti-crime operations. The public also can play a big part to help in this area. They can help by immediately reporting suspicious persons loitering around the vicinity. Indeed, such public cooperation and vigilance, in the opinion of the Police, contributed to a decline in housebreaking offences last year.

FINGER PIER IMMIGRATION CHECKPOINT
(Upgrading of facilities)


    10. Mr Eric Cheong Yuen Chee asked the Minister for Home Affairs whether he will look into the possibility of upgrading the facilities at the Finger Pier immigration checkpoint to provide faster clearance of tourists and others returning from tours to the Indonesian islands like Batam and Tanjong Pinang.

     Prof. Jayakumar: Mr Speaker, Sir, the Finger Pier Passenger Terminal was constructed by the Port of Singapore Autho-

Column: 16

rity in 1975 to cater to the ferry traffic between Singapore and the neighbouring Indonesian islands. With the development of Pulau Batam and Tanjong Pinang as holiday spots for Singaporeans and others over the last two years, there are now more people travelling to Indonesia via the Finger Pier checkpoint.

    The PSA and Immigration Department are monitoring the traffic and the capability of the existing facilities to handle it. Improvements are being made to the terminal building and, if necessary, PSA will review the situation. PSA is also working on long-term plans for a new site to build bigger and better facilities.

STOCKBROKING INDUSTRY
(Financial state)


    11. Mr Chng Hee Kok asked the Minister for Finance if he will give an assessment of the current financial state of the Singapore stockbroking industry.

     The Minister for Finance (Dr Richard Hu Tsu Tau): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Singapore stockbroking industry has survived the recent worldwide collapse in share prices remarkably well. The ST index fell a total of 31% between 19th October 1987 and 2nd November 1987. Due to a combination of international and regional factors, this fall was only exceeded by the decline in Hong Kong and was substantially larger than the falls in New York and Tokyo over the same period. The Stock Exchange of Singapore (SES) was also able to cope with sharp rises in turnover without any hiccups. This performance provides ample evidence of the fundamental soundness of the stockbroking industry.

    The present stability of the industry is a direct result of reforms introduced following the Pan-Electric crisis two years ago. They included the Securities Industry Act of 1986, the reconstitution of the Stock Exchange Committee, the corporatization of stockbroking firms, and the more recent introduction of revised rules on settlement and delivery.

    Bank borrowings of the stockbroking industry totalled $260 million as at 30th October 1987, compared to $1 billion two

Column: 17

years ago. These borrowings are well supported by aggregate shareholders' funds of $484 million so that stockbrokers are operating within the capital and debt-gearing criteria required in the Regulations.

    Stockbroking firms have extended only $100 million in margin financing to their clients and their own investment in stocks and underwriting exposures are relatively modest, amounting to $92 million and $53 million respectively. With a much improved capital base and a healthy flow of commission income, the firms are well placed to weather the present turmoil in the stock markets.

     Mr Jek Yeun Thong (Queenstown): Would the Minister now consider it wrong to allow CPF members to use their CPF money to buy shares in the stock exchange, people whom the Howe Yoon Chong Report not so long ago would like us to believe that they could not be trusted to look after their own savings and yet they are now allowed to participate in the stock exchange casino, speculating away their hard earned money on shares, gold, and heaven knows what?

     Dr Richard Hu Tsu Tau: Although the question is not relevant to the question being asked, I will nevertheless reply.

    I do not believe that it was a mistake and I think there is a presumption that all members who have used their CPF money have, in fact, lost money. This is not true. Some who have bought early should have made some money and those who have sold before the peak would also have made money. Undoubtedly there would be some who have taken on paper losses and one assumes that these people would not find it necessary to sell because the funds used were surplus to their immediate requirements and they should have bought only shares which were sensibly priced in the first place.

    It must be recognized that any investment carries a risk. The higher the rate of return one expects the higher the risk and one can assume that the majority of investors in Singapore are reasonably sensible, although one cannot exclude the possibility of those who want to speculate and therefore have to accept the risk.

CRISIS IN WORLD STOCK MARKETS
(Effect on Singapore's reserves)


    12. Mr S. Chandra Das asked the Minister for Finance what is the effect if any, of the present crisis in world stock markets in New York, London, Tokyo, Sydney, Hong Kong, etc, on our reserves invested overseas.

     Dr Richard Hu Tsu Tau: Sir, the Government has always maintained a conservative strategy in the management of its overseas assets. Our investments are mainly in Government bonds, with the balance divided between gold, cash, stocks and shares, and real estate.

    Our stock portfolio has declined in value in line with world stock markets but as the bulk of our portfolio was purchased over a period of several years since 1982, our investments still show very substantial real gains even at present prices. The present fall in share prices should also be seen in its proper context. The worldwide bull market in stocks started in 1982 and the recent stock market declines merely bring share prices back to levels last seen in late 1986 in the United States and early 1987 in Japan.

    We were also fortunate that when share prices fell, bond prices moved in the opposite direction, so that the declines in our stock portfolio were partly offset by gains in our bond portfolios. Overall, the present crisis in world stock markets has had little impact on our overseas investments.

    I should also mention that our equity purchase policies have always been a conservative one. We are long term investors, concentrating on a portfolio of strong, low price/earning multiple companies with a large market capitalization, all well placed to ride through economic downturns.

     Mr Chiam See Tong: Sir, can the Minister please tell us what is the percentage of the reserves that are invested in stock overseas?

     Dr Richard Hu Tsu Tau: We have never announced a breakdown of our investments and I do not propose to do so now.

UNEMPLOYMENT
(Measures to reduce)


    13. Encik Abbas Abu Amin asked the Minister for Labour what is the latest unemployment situation and whether his Ministry has plans (i) to encourage part-time employment, (ii) to persuade employers in the private sector to increase the retirement age of their workers and (iii) to monitor the supply and demand on foreign workers so as not to jeopardize our own people of job opportunities.

    14. Mr Lim Boon Heng asked the Minister for Labour what is the latest available unemployment rate.

     The Minister for Labour (Mr Lee Yock Suan): Mr Speaker, Sir, may I answer Questions 13 and 14 together as they overlap.

    The latest labour force survey in September 1987 shows that there were an estimated 44,700 unemployed persons, a decline of 14,100 persons from June 1987. This gives an unemployment rate of 3.6%, down from the 4.7% recorded in June 1987.

    With economic recovery, the unemployment situation has improved as many of the jobs created have been taken up by Singaporeans.

    My Ministry has been encouraging companies to employ more part-time workers as an additional source to meet their labour requirements. Our survey shows that about 27,000 housewives are interested to return to work. Of these, about 12,000 would like to work part-time. This is a potential pool of persons for employers to attract back to the workforce by devising part-time schemes with working hours which suit these women.
